error.title: Final Transfer-Encoding must be ‘chunked’
error.rfc: If any transfer coding other than chunked is applied to a request payload body, the sender MUST apply chunked as the final transfer coding to ensure that the message is properly framed.

error.title: Transfer-Encoding can’t have ‘chunked’ twice
error.rfc: A sender MUST NOT apply chunked more than once to a message body (i.e., chunking an already chunked message is not allowed).

debug.title: Not decoding Transfer-Encoding:
debug.explain: HTTPolice does not know how to decode the transfer coding. (This doesn’t mean that it’s wrong.)

error.title: Message is incomplete according to Content-Length
error.explain: This message’s Content-Length header indicates that the body is bytes long, but there are fewer bytes remaining on the stream .

debug.title: Stop parsing request stream
debug.explain: Due to previous notices, the data beginning at byte on the request stream will not be parsed.

error.title: Not enough requests
error.explain: There are unparsed bytes remaining on the response stream , but no requests that would correspond to them. HTTPolice will try to parse and analyze the remaining responses on their own.

debug.title: Stop parsing response stream
debug.explain: Due to previous notices, the data beginning at byte on the response stream will not be parsed.

debug.title: Switching protocols
debug.explain: The 101 status code means that the connection is switching to a different protocol. HTTPolice will not parse the rest of the streams.

debug.title: Switching to a tunnel
debug.explain: A response to a CONNECT request means that the connection is becoming a tunnel. HTTPolice will not parse the remainder of the streams.

error.title: Multiple headers are forbidden
error.rfc: A sender MUST NOT generate multiple header fields with the same field name in a message unless either the entire field value for that header field is defined as a comma-separated list [i.e., #(values)] or the header field is a well-known exception (as noted below).

comment.title: RWS in should be a single space
comment.explain: The syntax of includes the rule named RWS. It should be produced as just a single space, but here it was characters. See .

error.title: Bad whitespace (BWS) in
error.explain: The syntax of includes the rule named BWS, which is whitespace allowed for historical reasons; it must not be produced by current implementations. See .

error.title: Obsolete line folding in headers
error.explain: This message uses line folding (the “obs-fold” rule) to split one header field over several physical lines, but this is deprecated and prohibited in most cases. See .

comment.title: Strange escaping in
comment.explain: This message uses the “quoted-pair” rule to escape the character in a context where this escaping is unnecessary and should not be used. See .
If a literal backslash \ was intended here, it must itself be escaped as \\.

error.title: Transfer-Encoding is forbidden in a response
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT send a Transfer-Encoding header field in any response with a status code of 1xx (Informational) or 204 (No Content).

error.title: Transfer-Encoding is forbidden in a response to CONNECT
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT send a Transfer-Encoding header field in any 2xx (Successful) response to a CONNECT request

error.title: Can’t have both Transfer-Encoding and Content-Length
error.rfc: A sender MUST NOT send a Content-Length header field in any message that contains a Transfer-Encoding header field.

comment.title: request should have Content-Length
comment.rfc: A user agent SHOULD send a Content-Length in a request message when no Transfer-Encoding is sent and the request method defines a meaning for an enclosed payload body. For example, a Content-Length header field is normally sent in a POST request even when the value is 0 (indicating an empty payload body).

comment.title: Empty request shouldn’t have Content-Length
comment.rfc: A user agent SHOULD NOT send a Content-Length header field when the request message does not contain a payload body and the method semantics do not anticipate such a body.

error.title: Content-Length is forbidden in a response
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT send a Content-Length header field in any response with a status code of 1xx (Informational) or 204 (No Content).

error.title: Content-Length is forbidden in a response to CONNECT
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT send a Content-Length header field in any 2xx (Successful) response to a CONNECT request (Section 4.3.6 of [RFC7231]).

comment.title: Response delimited only by closing the connection
comment.explain: This response has no Content-Length header and no “Transfer-Encoding: chunked” that would delimit its body. Therefore, the body is assumed to consist of everything the server sends until closing the connection. But then the client cannot be sure that it received the entire response (that there were no network failures).
See .

error.title: is forbidden in a trailer
error.rfc: A sender MUST NOT generate a trailer that contains a field necessary for message framing (e.g., Transfer-Encoding and Content-Length), routing (e.g., Host), request modifiers (e.g., controls and conditionals in Section 5 of [RFC7231]), authentication (e.g., see [RFC7235] and [RFC6265]), response control data (e.g., see Section 7.1 of [RFC7231]), or determining how to process the payload (e.g., Content-Encoding, Content-Type, Content-Range, and Trailer).

error.title: “TE: chunked” is forbidden
error.rfc: A client MUST NOT send the chunked transfer coding name in TE; chunked is always acceptable for HTTP/1.1 recipients.

error.title: TE header requires “Connection: TE”
error.rfc: Since the TE header field only applies to the immediate connection, a sender of TE MUST also send a "TE" connection option within the Connection header field (Section 6.1) in order to prevent the TE field from being forwarded by intermediaries that do not support its semantics.

comment.title: was not announced in the Trailer header
comment.rfc: When a message includes a message body encoded with the chunked transfer coding and the sender desires to send metadata in the form of trailer fields at the end of the message, the sender SHOULD generate a Trailer header field before the message body to indicate which fields will be present in the trailers.

error.title: Missing Host header
error.rfc: A client MUST send a Host header field in all HTTP/1.1 request messages.

comment.title: Host should be the first header
comment.rfc: Since the Host field-value is critical information for handling a request, a user agent SHOULD generate Host as the first header field following the request-line.

error.title: Request with a bad Host header must be rejected
error.rfc: A server MUST respond with a 400 (Bad Request) status code to any HTTP/1.1 request message that lacks a Host header field and to any request message that contains more than one Host header field or a Host header field with an invalid field-value.

error.title: “Connection: ” is forbidden
error.rfc: A sender MUST NOT send a connection option corresponding to a header field that is intended for all recipients of the payload. For example, Cache-Control is never appropriate as a connection option (Section 5.2 of [RFC7234]).

comment.title: Deprecated media type
comment.explain: According to Content-Type, this message’s body is of type , which is listed as “deprecated” or “obsoleted” in the .

debug.title: Not decoding Content-Encoding:
debug.explain: HTTPolice does not know how to decode the content coding. (This doesn’t mean that it’s wrong.)

error.title: Bad JSON body
error.explain: According to Content-Type, this message’s body is JSON, but HTTPolice tried to parse it as JSON and got the following error:

error.title: Bad XML body
error.explain: According to Content-Type, this message’s body is XML, but HTTPolice tried to parse it as XML and got the following error:

error.title: Bad URL-encoded body
error.explain: According to Content-Type, this message’s body is URL-encoded. But it doesn’t look like a proper URL-encoded string, as defined by , because it contains the character: .
This often means that the Content-Type header is wrong.

comment.title: Body should have a Content-Type
comment.rfc: A sender that generates a message containing a payload body SHOULD generate a Content-Type header field in that message unless the intended media type of the enclosed representation is unknown to the sender.

comment.title: Duplicate ‘’ parameter in Content-Type
comment.rfc: It is an error for a specific parameter to be specified more than once.

error.title: Syntax error in request target
error.explain: See also .

error.title: Proxied response needs a Via header
error.explain: According to , a proxy must add a Via header to each response that it forwards.

comment.title: Close-delimited response should have “Connection: close”
comment.explain: When a response is delimited only by closing the connection, it should have a Connection header with a ‘close’ option. See and .

error.title: 101 response needs an Upgrade header
error.rfc: A server that sends a 101 (Switching Protocols) response MUST send an Upgrade header field to indicate the new protocol(s) to which the connection is being switched

error.title: Switching to a protocol that was not requested
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT switch to a protocol that was not indicated by the client in the corresponding request's Upgrade header field.

error.title: Upgrade header requires “Connection: upgrade”
error.rfc: When Upgrade is sent, the sender MUST also send a Connection header field (Section 6.1) that contains an "upgrade" connection option, in order to prevent Upgrade from being accidentally forwarded by intermediaries that might not implement the listed protocols.

error.title: 101 response to an HTTP/1.0 request is forbidden
error.rfc: A server MUST ignore an Upgrade header field that is received in an HTTP/1.0 request.

error.title: makes no sense in a response
error.explain: The header provides representation metadata, but there can be no representation associated with a response. The header should probably be removed.

comment.title: makes no sense in an empty request
comment.explain: The header provides representation metadata. It would make sense in a request with a body, but this one has no body.
See also .

error.title: Trailer header makes no sense without a chunked body
error.explain: The Trailer header announces what other headers will be sent in the trailer part of a chunked message. It doesn’t make sense here because this message does not use the chunked transfer coding.
See also .

comment.title: Unnecessary Content-Location
comment.explain: This is a response to a request. By definition, its body is a representation of the requested resource. But it also has a Content-Location header that points to the same URI as the request URI. In this case, the header provides no additional information.
See also .

comment.title: GET request with a body may cause problems
HEAD request with a body may cause problems

error.title: PUT request with Content-Range must be rejected
error.rfc: An origin server that allows PUT on a given target resource MUST send a 400 (Bad Request) response to a PUT request that contains a Content-Range header field (Section 4.2 of [RFC7233]), since the payload is likely to be partial content that has been mistakenly PUT as a full representation.

comment.title: DELETE request with a body may cause problems

error.title: Strange Content-Location in response to DELETE
error.explain: This is an ostensibly successful () response to a DELETE request. However, according to its Content-Location header, it carries a representation of the target resource—the one that should have been deleted. Either the Content-Location is wrong, or the request did not actually succeed.

comment.title: CONNECT request with a body may cause problems

error.title: OPTIONS request with a body needs Content-Type
error.rfc: A client that generates an OPTIONS request containing a payload body MUST send a valid Content-Type header field describing the representation media type.

error.title: header is for responses
error.explain: This request has the header, which is only defined for responses.

error.title: header is for requests
error.explain: This response has the header, which is only defined for requests.

error.title: “Expect: 100-continue” is forbidden on empty requests
error.rfc: A client MUST NOT generate a 100-continue expectation in a request that does not include a message body.

comment.title: Max-Forwards header is undefined for requests
comment.explain: The Max-Forwards header is only defined for OPTIONS and TRACE requests. A recipient MAY ignore a Max-Forwards header field received with any other request methods.

error.title: Unsecured request must not have a Referer with ‘https:’
error.rfc: A user agent MUST NOT send a Referer header field in an unsecured HTTP request if the referring page was received with a secure protocol.

comment.title: Missing User-Agent header
comment.rfc: A user agent SHOULD send a User-Agent field in each request unless specifically configured not to do so.

error.title: response to an HTTP/1.0 request is forbidden
error.rfc: Since HTTP/1.0 did not define any 1xx status codes, a server MUST NOT send a 1xx response to an HTTP/1.0 client.

error.title: 201 response to makes no sense
error.explain: The method is defined as safe (read-only). But the 201 status code means that a new resource was created.

comment.title: Possibly missing Location header
comment.explain: This 201 response indicates that a new resource was created. Because there is no Location header in the response, it is assumed that the created resource is the same as the request target (). But POST requests are usually intended to create a sub-resource of the target. It’s likely that this response needs an explicit Location.

error.title: 202 response to makes no sense
error.explain: The method is defined as safe (read-only). But the 202 status code means that the server started some kind of processing operation.

error.title: 205 response must not have a body
error.rfc: Since the 205 status code implies that no additional content will be provided, a server MUST NOT generate a payload in a 205 response.

comment.title: 300 response should have a body
comment.rfc: For request methods other than HEAD, the server SHOULD generate a payload in the 300 response containing a list of representation metadata and URI reference(s) from which the user or user agent can choose the one most preferred.

comment.title: 301 response should have a Location header
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a Location header field in the response containing a preferred URI reference for the new permanent URI.

comment.title: 302 response should have a Location header
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a Location header field in the response containing a URI reference for the different URI.

error.title: 303 response needs a Location header
error.rfc: The 303 (See Other) status code indicates that the server is redirecting the user agent to a different resource, as indicated by a URI in the Location header field, which is intended to provide an indirect response to the original request.

comment.title: 303 response should have a body
comment.rfc: Except for responses to a HEAD request, the representation of a 303 response ought to contain a short hypertext note with a hyperlink to the same URI reference provided in the Location header field.

error.title: Status code 305 is deprecated
error.rfc: The 305 (Use Proxy) status code was defined in a previous version of this specification and is now deprecated (Appendix B).

error.title: Status code 306 is reserved
error.rfc: The 306 status code was defined in a previous version of this specification, is no longer used, and the code is reserved.

comment.title: 307 response should have a Location header
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a Location header field in the response containing a URI reference for the different URI.

error.title: Redirection to the same URI
error.explain: This response includes a Location header that points to the same URI as the request URI. So the resource redirects to itself.

error.title: response to server-wide OPTIONS makes no sense
error.explain: The status code means that the target resource can be found at a different URI. But this was an “ OPTIONS * ” request—it targets the entire server, not any particular resource. So the status code makes no sense here.
Perhaps the 303 status code would fit better.

comment.title: response should include an explanation
comment.rfc: Except when responding to a HEAD request, the server SHOULD send a representation containing an explanation of the error situation, and whether it is a temporary or permanent condition.

error.title: Status code 402 is reserved
error.rfc: The 402 (Payment Required) status code is reserved for future use.

error.title: 405 response needs an Allow header
error.rfc: The origin server MUST generate an Allow header field in a 405 response containing a list of the target resource's currently supported methods.

error.title: 406 response, but request wasn’t negotiating
error.explain: The 406 status code means that the server cannot satisfy the request’s content negotiation headers, such as Accept. But this request doesn’t seem to have such headers.
See also .

comment.title: 406 response should have a body
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a payload containing a list of available representation characteristics and corresponding resource identifiers from which the user or user agent can choose the one most appropriate.

comment.title: User-Agent contains no actual product
comment.explain: This request’s User-Agent header contains only the name of the underlying library, which isn’t very useful for identifying the request. It may be a good idea to include the name of the actual product.
For example: “My-Product/1.0 ”.
Or simply “My-Product/1.0” or “My-Product”.
See .

comment.title: 408 response should have “Connection: close”
comment.rfc: A server SHOULD send the "close" connection option (Section 6.1 of [RFC7230]) in the response, since 408 implies that the server has decided to close the connection rather than continue waiting.

error.title: 409 response to makes no sense
error.explain: The 409 status code means that the request conflicted with the current state of the resource. But a request is, by definition, safe (read-only): it must not affect the state, so there can be no conflict.

comment.title: 409 response should include an explanation
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a payload that includes enough information for a user to recognize the source of the conflict.

error.title: 411 response, but request did have Content-Length
error.explain: The 411 status code means that the server wants to see a Content-Length header in the request. But this request did, in fact, include a valid Content-Length of .

error.title: 413 response, but request had no body
error.rfc: The 413 (Payload Too Large) status code indicates that the server is refusing to process a request because the request payload is larger than the server is willing or able to process.

error.title: 415 response, but request had no body
error.rfc: The 415 (Unsupported Media Type) status code indicates that the origin server is refusing to service the request because the payload is in a format not supported by this method on the target resource.

error.title: 417 response, but request had no Expect
error.rfc: The 417 (Expectation Failed) status code indicates that the expectation given in the request's Expect header field (Section 5.1.1) could not be met by at least one of the inbound servers.

error.title: 426 response needs an Upgrade header
error.rfc: The server MUST send an Upgrade header field in a 426 response to indicate the required protocol(s)

error.title: 426 response, but client is ready to upgrade
error.explain: In this response, the server demands that the client upgrade to . But the client’s request is already offering that same upgrade in its own Upgrade header. The server can just send a 101 response and switch to .
See .

error.title: Not proceeding with protocol upgrade
error.explain: This response’s Upgrade header indicates that the server is ready to upgrade to . But the client’s request is already offering that same upgrade in its own Upgrade header. If the server actually wants to switch to , it should go ahead, send a 101 response, and switch.
See .

comment.title: response should include an explanation
comment.rfc: Except when responding to a HEAD request, the server SHOULD send a representation containing an explanation of the error situation, and whether it is a temporary or permanent condition.

error.title: 505 response, but request had the same HTTP version
error.explain: The 505 status code means that the server does not support the HTTP version used in the request—which is —but the response itself is , too.
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT send a version to which it is not conformant.

comment.title: 505 response should have a body
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a representation for the 505 response that describes why that version is not supported and what other protocols are supported by that server.

error.title: Obsolete date-time format in
error.explain: This message’s uses an obsolete date-time format. See .

error.title: Wrong day of week in
error.explain: This message’s claims that is , but in reality it’s .

error.title: Date header is in the future
error.explain: The Date header contains the date and time at which the message was originated. But here it seems to be in the future.
This might be due to wrong timezone settings.

comment.title: Missing Date header
comment.explain: According to , every response must have a Date header, unless the server has no usable clock.

error.title: 201 response can’t have Location with a fragment (#)
error.rfc: There are circumstances in which a fragment identifier in a Location value would not be appropriate. For example, the Location header field in a 201 (Created) response is supposed to provide a URI that is specific to the created resource.

comment.title: Location header is undefined for responses
comment.explain: does not define what it means for a response to have a Location header.

comment.title: Retry-After is undefined for responses
comment.explain: As far as HTTPolice knows, the Retry-After header is defined for status codes 3xx, 413, 429, and 503, but not for .

error.title: 405 response, but Allow includes
error.explain: The 405 status code means that the request method () is not allowed for this resource. But the Allow header does include .

error.title: Allow does not include
error.explain: The status code means that this request was handled successfully. But the Allow header does not include , so it should have been disallowed (status code 405).

error.title: Accept-Encoding: must not have a quality value
error.rfc: Most HTTP/1.0 applications do not recognize or obey qvalues associated with content-codings. This means that qvalues might not work and are not permitted with x-gzip or x-compress.

comment.title: Accept-Language shouldn’t trigger a 406 response
comment.explain: The 406 status code means that the server cannot satisfy the request’s content negotiation headers. The only such header (known to HTTPolice) in this request is Accept-Language. However, discourages sending a 406 response in this case: it’s better to send a representation in a different language, because the user may still be able to understand some of it.

error.title: Last-Modified can’t be later than Date
error.rfc: An origin server with a clock MUST NOT send a Last-Modified date that is later than the server's time of message origination (Date).

comment.title: Backslash in may cause problems
comment.rfc: Previously, opaque-tag was defined to be a quoted-string ([RFC2616], Section 3.11); thus, some recipients might perform backslash unescaping. Servers therefore ought to avoid backslash characters in entity tags.

error.title: Weak entity tag in If-Match is not supposed to work
error.rfc: An origin server MUST use the strong comparison function when comparing entity-tags for If-Match (Section 2.3.2), since the client intends this precondition to prevent the method from being applied if there have been any changes to the representation data.
error.explain: In other words, a conformant server will never consider two weak entity tags as equal for purposes of the If-Match header.

error.title: If-None-Match was ignored
error.explain: This is a response to a request, but its ETag header matches the If-None-Match header of the request. The server is supposed to send a 304 response in this situation.
See .

error.title: If-Modified-Since in requests is not supposed to work
error.explain: According to , an If-Modified-Since header must be ignored in requests that are neither GET nor HEAD.

comment.title: If-Modified-Since was ignored
comment.explain: This is a response to a request, but its Last-Modified date is no later than the If-Modified-Since header of the request. The server should send a 304 response in this situation.
See .

error.title: 304 response is undefined for requests
error.explain: The 304 status code is only defined by for responses to GET and HEAD. With other methods, the 412 status code may be useful.

error.title: response, but request has no preconditions
error.explain: The status code is only used when the request includes a precondition, such as If-Modified-Since. But this request doesn’t seem to have any preconditions.
See .

comment.title: 304 response should not have
comment.rfc: Since the goal of a 304 response is to minimize information transfer when the recipient already has one or more cached representations, a sender SHOULD NOT generate representation metadata other than the above listed fields unless said metadata exists for the purpose of guiding cache updates (e.g., Last-Modified might be useful if the response does not have an ETag field).

error.title: If-Modified-Since on must be ignored
error.explain: The 412 status code means that the server could not satisfy a precondition included in the request. The only such precondition (known to HTTPolice) in this request is If-Modified-Since. But says that an If-Modified-Since header in a request must be ignored.

error.title: Preconditions on must be ignored
error.explain: The 412 status code means that the server could not satisfy a precondition included in the request. But, as defined in , such preconditions must be ignored in a request.

error.title: on makes no sense
error.rfc: Likewise, a server MUST ignore the conditional request header fields defined by this specification when received with a request method that does not involve the selection or modification of a selected representation, such as CONNECT, OPTIONS, or TRACE.

comment.title: Conditional HEAD request is pointless
comment.rfc: Although conditional request header fields are defined as being usable with the HEAD method (to keep HEAD's semantics consistent with those of GET), there is no point in sending a conditional HEAD because a successful response is around the same size as a 304 (Not Modified) response and more useful than a 412 (Precondition Failed) response.

error.title: Range header on is not supposed to work
error.rfc: A server MUST ignore a Range header field received with a request method other than GET.

error.title: Invalid byte range in
error.rfc: A byte-range-spec is invalid if the last-byte-pos value is present and less than the first-byte-pos.

error.title: If-Range requires a Range header
error.rfc: A client MUST NOT generate an If-Range header field in a request that does not contain a Range header field.

error.title: Weak entity tags are forbidden in If-Range
error.rfc: A client MUST NOT generate an If-Range header field containing an entity-tag that is marked as weak.

error.title: 206 response, but request had no Range
error.explain: The 206 status code only makes sense in responses to partial requests—that is, requests with a Range header. See .

error.title: 206 response to is forbidden
error.rfc: A server MUST ignore a Range header field received with a request method other than GET.

error.title: 206 response needs range specifiers
error.explain: The 206 status code means that the response contains one or more parts of the data. When it contains one part, the response must have a Content-Range header. When it contains several parts, the response must have a Content-Type of multipart/byteranges. But this response has neither.
See .

error.title: Multipart boundary not declared
error.explain: According to Content-Type, this message has a multipart body, but Content-Type does not include the ‘boundary’ parameter that is necessary to parse such a body.
See .

error.title: Multipart boundary not found
error.explain: The multipart boundary declared in this message’s Content-Type was not found in the body.
See .

error.title: No Content-Range in part #
error.rfc: Within the header area of each body part in the multipart payload, the server MUST generate a Content-Range header field corresponding to the range being enclosed in that body part.

comment.title: No Content-Type in part #
comment.rfc: If the selected representation would have had a Content-Type header field in a 200 (OK) response, the server SHOULD generate that same Content-Type field in the header area of each body part.

error.title: Content-Range in a multipart/byteranges response is forbidden
error.rfc: To avoid confusion with single-part responses, a server MUST NOT generate a Content-Range header field in the HTTP header section of a multiple part response (this field will be sent in each part instead).

error.title: multipart/byteranges response can’t be used for a single Range
error.rfc: A server MUST NOT generate a multipart response to a request for a single range, since a client that does not request multiple parts might not support multipart responses.

error.title: 206 response, but ETag doesn’t match If-Range
error.explain: The request’s If-Range header means that the server is expected to send a 206 response only if the representation’s ETag matches the one specified in If-Range. In this case, it doesn’t match, so the server is supposed to send a 200 response with the complete data.
See .

comment.title: Unnecessary header
comment.rfc: If a 206 is generated in response to a request with an If-Range header field, the sender SHOULD NOT generate other representation header fields beyond those required above, because the client is understood to already have a prior response containing those header fields.

error.title: Content-Range is undefined for responses
error.explain: The Content-Range header is defined by for responses with status codes 206 and 416, but not .

error.title: Invalid byte range in
error.rfc: A Content-Range field value is invalid if it contains a byte-range-resp that has a last-byte-pos value less than its first-byte-pos value, or a complete-length value less than or equal to its last-byte-pos value.

error.title: 416 response to request without Range makes no sense
error.explain: The 416 status code is defined by only for responses to requests that have a Range header.

comment.title: 416 response should have Content-Range
comment.rfc: When this status code is generated in response to a byte-range request, the sender SHOULD generate a Content-Range header field specifying the current length of the selected representation

error.title: Empty list elements in are forbidden
error.rfc: In any production that uses the list construct, a sender MUST NOT generate empty list elements.

error.title: Cache-Control: is for responses
error.explain: This request’s Cache-Control header includes the directive, which is only defined for responses.

error.title: Cache-Control: is for requests
error.explain: This response’s Cache-Control header includes the directive, which is only defined for requests.

comment.title: Cache-Control: should be quoted
comment.explain: The specification for the directive recommends wrapping its argument in double quotes. But in this message’s Cache-Control header, it is not quoted.

comment.title: Cache-Control: should not be quoted
comment.explain: In this message’s Cache-Control header, the argument to the directive is wrapped in double quotes. But the specification recommends writing it as a plain token, without quotes.

error.title: : needs an argument
error.explain: According to the specification, ‘’ in must have an argument. But in this message, it doesn’t.

error.title: : can’t have an argument
error.explain: In this message’s header, ‘’ has an argument. But the specification defines no argument for ‘’.

error.title: Syntax error in :
error.explain: “” is not a correct value for ‘’ in .

error.title: Cache-Control: no-cache can’t have an argument
error.explain: In this request’s Cache-Control header, the no-cache directive has an argument. But the specification for no-cache only defines an argument when used in responses.

comment.title: Pragma other than ‘no-cache’ is deprecated
comment.explain: This message’s Pragma header includes ‘’, but all pragmas other than ‘no-cache’ are deprecated in .

comment.title: “Cache-Control: no-cache” should also have “Pragma: no-cache”
comment.rfc: When sending a no-cache request, a client ought to include both the pragma and cache-control directives, unless Cache-Control: no-cache is purposefully omitted to target other Cache-Control response directives at HTTP/1.1 caches.

comment.title: Pragma: no-cache is for requests
comment.explain: This response contains the ‘no-cache’ pragma directive, which is defined by only for requests.

error.title: Warn code not in range 100—299
error.explain: defines two classes of warn codes: 1xx and 2xx. But this message’s Warning header contains a code.

error.title: Warning date must match the Date header
error.explain: This message’s Warning header contains a warning (code ) with a date that does not match the Date header. This means that the warning was mistakenly kept after cache validation. As explained in , such warnings must be removed.

error.title: “Warning: ” is for responses
error.explain: This request’s Warning header contains the warn code. But, according to , 1xx warn codes can only be used on responses.

error.title: Response from cache needs an Age header
error.explain: According to , a cache must add an Age header to every response that is served without contacting the origin server.

error.title: Status code not in range 100—599
error.explain: According to , HTTP status codes can only range from 100 to 599.

debug.title: Age header implies response from cache
debug.rfc: The presence of an Age header field implies that the response was not generated or validated by the origin server for this request.

debug.title: “Warning: ” implies response from cache
debug.explain: This response’s Warning header contains the warn code, which implies that it was served from a cache, without contacting the origin server. See .

comment.title: Response from cache older than max-age
comment.explain: This response’s Age of is greater than the max-age of requested by the client’s Cache-Control header.

comment.title: Cache-Control: has no effect on
comment.explain: The method is defined as non-cacheable, so the directive in this request’s Cache-Control header makes no difference.

error.title: Response to can’t be served from cache
error.explain: The method is defined as non-cacheable.

error.title: Response to “Cache-Control: no-cache” can’t be served from cache
error.rfc: The "no-cache" request directive indicates that a cache MUST NOT use a stored response to satisfy the request without successful validation on the origin server.

error.title: Response to “Pragma: no-cache” can’t be served from cache
error.rfc: When the Cache-Control header field is not present in a request, caches MUST consider the no-cache request pragma-directive as having the same effect as if "Cache-Control: no-cache" were present

error.title: Response with “Cache-Control: no-cache” can’t be served from cache
error.rfc: The "no-cache" response directive indicates that the response MUST NOT be used to satisfy a subsequent request without successful validation on the origin server.

error.title: Response with “Cache-Control: no-store” can’t be served from cache
error.explain: According to , a cache cannot store a response that includes the no-store directive in its Cache-Control header.

error.title: response can’t be served from cache by default
error.explain: The status code is not defined as cacheable by default. According to , such a response can only be cached if it explicitly allows caching, with headers such as Expires. But this response has no such headers, so it is not cacheable.

debug.title: Heuristic freshness
debug.explain: Because this response has no explicit freshness controls (such as Expires or max-age), HTTPolice will assume that its expiration time was chosen heuristically by the cache. See .

debug.title: “Warning: 113” implies heuristic freshness
debug.explain: The 113 warn code in this response’s Warning header means that the expiration time for this response was chosen heuristically by the cache.

comment.title: Heuristic freshness should have “Warning: 113”
comment.rfc: When a heuristic is used to calculate freshness lifetime, a cache SHOULD generate a Warning header field with a 113 warn-code (see Section 5.5.4) in the response if its current_age is more than 24 hours and such a warning is not already present.

error.title: Heuristic freshness can’t be used when Expires is present
error.rfc: A cache MUST NOT use heuristics to determine freshness when an explicit expiration time is present in the stored response.

error.title: Heuristic freshness can’t be used when max-age is present
error.rfc: A cache MUST NOT use heuristics to determine freshness when an explicit expiration time is present in the stored response.

comment.title: “Warning: ” implies response is stale
comment.explain: The warn code in this response’s Warning header means that the response is stale, as defined by .

comment.title: Response is stale because Age > max-age
comment.explain: This response’s Age is greater than the max-age specified in its Cache-Control header. This means that the response is stale, as defined by .

comment.title: Response is stale because Age > Expires − Date
comment.explain: This response’s Age is greater than the difference between its Expires date and its Date header. This means that the response is stale, as defined by .

comment.title: Stale response should have “Warning: 110”
comment.rfc: A cache SHOULD generate a Warning header field with the 110 warn-code (see Section 5.5.1) in stale responses.

error.title: Response with “Cache-Control: must-revalidate” can’t be served stale
error.rfc: The "must-revalidate" response directive indicates that once it has become stale, a cache MUST NOT use the response to satisfy subsequent requests without successful validation on the origin server.

comment.title: Possibly wrong stale response
comment.rfc: A cache MUST NOT send stale responses unless it is disconnected (i.e., it cannot contact the origin server or otherwise find a forward path) or doing so is explicitly allowed (e.g., by the max-stale request directive; see Section 5.2.1).
comment.explain: If the cache is disconnected, it should have added a Warning header with a 112 or 111 warn code to indicate that.

debug.title: “Warning: 214” means transformed by proxy
debug.explain: The 214 warn code in this message’s Warning header means that it was transformed by a proxy.

debug.title: Status 203 means transformed by proxy
debug.explain: The 203 status code means that this response was transformed by a proxy.

error.title: Transformed message needs “Warning: 214”
error.rfc: A proxy that transforms a payload MUST add a Warning header field with the warn-code of 214 ("Transformation Applied") if one is not already in the message (see Section 5.5 of [RFC7234]).

error.title: Transformation forbidden by “Cache-Control: no-transform”
error.rfc: A proxy MUST NOT transform the payload (Section 3.3 of [RFC7231]) of a message that contains a no-transform cache-control directive (Section 5.2 of [RFC7234]).

error.title: Cache-Control: contradicts
error.explain: This message’s Cache-Control header includes both the and the directives, which contradict each other.

error.title: 401 response needs a WWW-Authenticate header
error.rfc: The server generating a 401 response MUST send a WWW-Authenticate header field (Section 4.1) containing at least one challenge applicable to the target resource.

error.title: 407 response needs a Proxy-Authenticate header
error.rfc: The proxy MUST send a Proxy-Authenticate header field (Section 4.3) containing a challenge applicable to that proxy for the target resource.

error.title: ‘realm’ parameter in must be quoted
error.explain: According to , the value of the ‘realm’ parameter must be enclosed in double quotes.

comment.title: Deprecated header
comment.explain: This message has the header, which is listed as “obsoleted” or “deprecated” in the .

error.title: “Connection: close” makes no sense in response
error.explain: The status code means that this is an interim response, and more responses will follow on the same connection. But the ‘close’ option in this response’s Connection header means that the server will close the connection after sending this response.

error.title: “Connection: close” makes no sense in response to CONNECT
error.explain: A response to a CONNECT request means that this connection is becoming a tunnel. But the ‘close’ option in this response’s Connection header means that the server will close the connection after sending this response.

comment.title: 428 response, but request has a precondition
comment.explain: The 428 status code means that the server refuses to handle an unconditional request. But this request is conditional, because it has the header.

comment.title: 428 response should include an explanation
comment.rfc: Responses using this status code SHOULD explain how to resubmit the request successfully.

error.title: response can’t be served from cache
error.explain: According to the specification, the status code cannot be served from a cache.

comment.title: 429 response should include an explanation
comment.rfc: The response representations SHOULD include details explaining the condition, and MAY include a Retry-After header indicating how long to wait before making a new request.

comment.title: 511 response should have a body
comment.rfc: The response representation SHOULD contain a link to a resource that allows the user to submit credentials (e.g., with an HTML form).

comment.title: 308 response should have a Location header
comment.rfc: The server SHOULD generate a Location header field ([RFC7231], Section 7.1.2) in the response containing a preferred URI reference for the new permanent URI.

error.title: : Basic must have ‘realm’
error.explain: The Basic authentication scheme requires a ‘realm’ parameter. See .

error.title: : Basic can’t have a ‘’ parameter
error.explain: No ‘’ parameter is defined for the Basic authentication scheme. See .

error.title: : Basic can’t have a ‘’ charset
error.explain: According to , the ‘charset’ parameter to the Basic authentication scheme can only have the value “UTF-8”.

error.title: Malformed : Basic
error.explain: In the Basic authentication scheme, credentials are sent as a single Base64 string. See .

error.title: Malformed : Basic
error.explain: In the Basic authentication scheme, the user ID and password are combined with a colon ‘:’ and packed into Base64. In this request’s header, HTTPolice tried to decode them from Base64 and got the following error:
See .

error.title: Malformed : Basic
error.explain: In the Basic authentication scheme, the user ID and password are combined with a colon ‘:’ and packed into Base64. But in this request’s header, there is no ‘:’ after decoding from Base64. See .

error.title: : Basic can’t contain character
error.rfc: The user-id and password MUST NOT contain any control characters (see "CTL" in Appendix B.1 of [RFC5234]).

comment.title: Content-Type: is not suitable for PATCH
comment.explain: The PATCH method should only be used with media types that define how to apply the patch. is not such a media type.
See .
For example, application/merge-patch+json would be a suitable patch format for JSON.

comment.title: patch should be rejected
comment.rfc: If a server receives a PATCH request with a media type whose specification does not define semantics specific to PATCH, the server SHOULD reject the request by returning the 415 Unsupported Media Type status code, unless a more specific error status code takes priority.

comment.title: 415 response to PATCH should have Accept-Patch
comment.rfc: Such a response SHOULD include an Accept-Patch response header as described in Section 3.1 to notify the client what patch document media types are supported.

comment.title: Should send Accept-Patch with “Allow: PATCH”
comment.explain: This OPTIONS response indicates in its Allow header that the PATCH method is supported. According to , in this case the server should also send an Accept-Patch header.

error.title: Accept-Patch implies “Allow: PATCH”
error.explain: This response’s Accept-Patch header means that this resource supports the PATCH method, but it’s missing from the Allow header.

error.title: HSTS needs a ‘max-age’ directive
error.explain: According to , a Strict-Transport-Security header must have a max-age directive.

comment.title: HSTS: includeSubDomains has no effect with max-age=0
comment.explain: The “max-age=0” directive in this response’s Strict-Transport-Security header tells the user agent to delete the HSTS policy for the domain. The includeSubDomains directive makes no difference in this case.
See .

error.title: Duplicate ‘’ directive in HSTS
error.rfc: All directives MUST appear only once in an STS header field.

error.title: Strict-Transport-Security can’t be used without TLS
error.rfc: An HSTS Host MUST NOT include the STS header field in HTTP responses conveyed over non-secure transport.

error.title: Impossible date in
error.explain: “” is not a valid date.

error.title: Impossible time in
error.explain: “” is not a valid time.

error.title: LF without CR in
error.explain: Lines in HTTP message framing are terminated by two bytes: a carriage return (CR) followed by a line feed (LF). Some implementations accept a bare LF without CR, like in this message, but this is not reliable.
See also .

error.title: Duplicate ‘’ parameter in
error.explain: According to , the ‘’ parameter must not occur more than once in a single link.

comment.title: Deprecated ‘rev’ parameter in
comment.rfc: "rev" is deprecated by this specification because it often confuses authors and readers; in most cases, using a separate relation type is preferable.

comment.title: is not suitable for Accept-Patch
comment.explain: The PATCH method should only be used with media types that define how to apply the patch. is not such a media type. But this response’s Accept-Patch header invites the client to send patches of type .
See .
For example, application/merge-patch+json would be a suitable patch format for JSON.

error.title: Upgrade: h2 is wrong
error.explain: This message’s Upgrade header includes the token ‘h2’, which normally refers to HTTP/2 over TLS. But HTTP/2 over TLS does not use the Upgrade mechanism, and cleartext HTTP/2 uses the ‘h2c’ token instead, so “Upgrade: h2” is wrong.
See .

error.title: HTTP2-Settings needs “Connection: http2-settings”
error.rfc: Since the upgrade is only intended to apply to the immediate connection, a client sending the HTTP2-Settings header field MUST also send "HTTP2-Settings" as a connection option in the Connection header field to prevent it from being forwarded

error.title: Upgrade: h2c needs HTTP2-Settings
error.rfc: A request that upgrades from HTTP/1.1 to HTTP/2 MUST include exactly one "HTTP2-Settings" header field.

error.title: Upgrading to HTTP/2 despite bad HTTP2-Settings
error.explain: According to , the server must not upgrade to HTTP/2 unless the request has exactly one valid HTTP2-Settings header.

error.title: Upgrade: h2c can’t be used on a TLS connection
error.explain: An “Upgrade: h2c” header is used to switch to HTTP/2 from a cleartext HTTP/1.1 connection. But this message was sent on an encrypted (TLS) connection. HTTP/2 over TLS is negotiated by other means.
See .

error.title: Malformed HTTP2-Settings
error.explain: According to , the HTTP2-Settings header must use the URL- and filename-safe Base64 encoding without padding. This means that it can only contain letters, digits, dash (-), and underscore (_).

comment.title: Vary: Host is useless
comment.explain: There is no need to include Host in the Vary header, because Host is part of the request URI, and therefore, every HTTP response implicitly varies by Host already. “Vary: Host” can only scare caches away from storing the response.
See and .

debug.title: Absolute URI implies request to proxy
debug.explain: This request’s target is an absolute URI. According to , HTTP/1.1 clients only use this “absolute form” when connecting to proxies. Therefore, HTTPolice assumes that this request is to a proxy.

error.title: Response to a direct request can’t be transformed by a proxy
error.explain: It seems like this response was transformed by a proxy, but the request was not directed to a proxy.

comment.title: Cache-Control: has no effect with
comment.explain: This response’s Cache-Control header includes both the and the directives. But makes no difference when is present.

error.title: Response to HEAD can’t have a body
error.rfc: The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST NOT send a message body in the response

error.title: 204 response can’t have a body
error.rfc: The 204 (No Content) status code indicates that the server has successfully fulfilled the request and that there is no additional content to send in the response payload body.

error.title: Date + Age is in the future
error.explain: The Date header is the date and time when the response was originated. And the Age header is how long the response has been cached since then (or since it was revalidated). But in this response, the sum of Date + Age is in the future, so one of them must be wrong.
This can happen when a cache mistakenly changes the Date header, or adds an Age header even though it is not a true HTTP cache (according to ).
Also, this error can be caused by wrong timezone settings.

comment.title: 451 response should include an explanation
comment.rfc: Responses using this status code SHOULD include an explanation, in the response body, of the details of the legal demand: the party making it, the applicable legislation or regulation, and what classes of person and resource it applies to.

comment.title: 451 response should have a blocked-by link
comment.rfc: When an entity blocks access to a resource and returns status 451, it SHOULD include a "Link" HTTP header field [RFC5988] whose value is a URI reference [RFC3986] identifying itself. When used for this purpose, the "Link" header field MUST have a "rel" parameter whose value is "blocked-by".

error.title: header can’t be used in HTTP/2
error.rfc: An endpoint MUST NOT generate an HTTP/2 message containing connection-specific header fields
The only exception to this is the TE header field, which MAY be present in an HTTP/2 request; when it is, it MUST NOT contain any value other than "trailers".

error.title: Upgrade header can’t be used in HTTP/2
error.rfc: HTTP/2 purposefully does not support upgrade to another protocol.

error.title: 101 response can’t be used in HTTP/2
error.rfc: HTTP/2 removes support for the 101 (Switching Protocols) informational status code

error.title: Duplicate ‘’ parameter in Content-Disposition
error.rfc: Content-Disposition header field values with multiple instances of the same parameter name are invalid.

comment.title: Percent-encoded filename in Content-Disposition may cause problems
comment.rfc: Avoid including the percent character followed by two hexadecimal characters (e.g., %A9) in the filename parameter, since some existing implementations consider it to be an escape character, while others will pass it through unchanged.
comment.explain: Such a filename can be sent in the special ‘filename*’ parameter instead. See .

comment.title: Backslash in filename in Content-Disposition may cause problems
comment.rfc: Avoid including the "\" character in the quoted-string form of the filename parameter, as escaping is not implemented by some user agents, and "\" can be considered an illegal path character.
comment.explain: Such a filename can be sent in the special ‘filename*’ parameter instead. See .

comment.title: Non-ASCII filename in Content-Disposition may cause problems
comment.rfc: Avoid using non-ASCII characters in the filename parameter. Although most existing implementations will decode them as ISO-8859-1, some will apply heuristics to detect UTF-8, and thus might fail on certain names.
comment.explain: Such a filename can be sent in the special ‘filename*’ parameter instead. See .

comment.title: Content-Disposition: ‘filename*’ should also have ‘filename’ as fallback
comment.rfc: When a "filename*" parameter is sent, to also generate a "filename" parameter as a fallback for user agents that do not support the "filename*" form, if possible.

comment.title: Content-Disposition: ‘filename*’ should come after ‘filename’
comment.rfc: When a "filename" parameter is included as a fallback (as per above), "filename" should occur first, due to parsing problems in some existing implementations.

error.title: Bad charset ‘’ in
error.rfc: Producers MUST use either the "UTF-8" ([RFC3629]) or the "ISO-8859-1" ([ISO-8859-1]) character set. Extension character sets (mime- charset) are reserved for future use.

error.title: Bad value in
error.explain: This message’s contains a encoded value in the form defined by . But HTTPolice tried to decode it from and got the following error:

comment.title: Content-Disposition: filename* should be in UTF-8
comment.rfc: Use UTF-8 as the encoding of the "filename*" parameter, when present, because at least one existing implementation only implements that encoding.

error.title: Bad encoding of protocol ID in Alt-Svc
error.explain: This message’s Alt-Svc contains a protocol ID encoded as “”. But according to , it must be encoded as “”.

error.title: Malformed authority in Alt-Svc
error.explain: “” is not a valid Alt-Svc authority, according to .

comment.title: HTTP/2 should use ALTSVC frame instead of Alt-Svc header
comment.explain: recommends using ALTSVC frames instead of the Alt-Svc header on HTTP/2 connections.

error.title: 421 response can’t have Alt-Svc
error.rfc: An Alt-Svc header field in a 421 (Misdirected Request) response MUST be ignored.

error.title: Authorization: Bearer requires TLS
error.rfc: Clients MUST always use TLS [RFC5246] (https) or equivalent transport security when making requests with bearer tokens. Failing to do so exposes the token to numerous attacks that could give attackers unintended access.

error.title: Malformed Authorization: Bearer
error.explain: In the Bearer authentication scheme, credentials are sent as a single token. See .

error.title: WWW-Authenticate: Bearer requires TLS
error.explain: According to , bearer tokens must not be used without TLS. Instead of prompting the client to send a token on an insecure connection, perhaps it would be better to redirect to an ‘https:’ URI first.

error.title: Malformed WWW-Authenticate: Bearer
error.explain: A Bearer authentication challenge must have “key=value” parameters. See .

error.title: Duplicate ‘’ parameter in “WWW-Authenticate: Bearer”
error.explain: According to , the ‘’ parameter must not appear more than once.

error.title: Malformed ‘’ parameter in WWW-Authenticate
error.explain: “” is not a correct value for a ‘’ parameter in a Bearer challenge. See .

comment.title: Declined a Bearer token, but no ‘error’ parameter
comment.rfc: If the protected resource request included an access token and failed authentication, the resource server SHOULD include the "error" attribute to provide the client with the reason why the access request was declined.

comment.title: Response with “error=” should be
comment.explain: According to , when the server’s Bearer challenge has “error=”, the status code should be .

comment.title: Unneeded ‘’ in WWW-Authenticate
comment.rfc: If the request lacks any authentication information (e.g., the client was unaware that authentication is necessary or attempted using an unsupported authentication method), the resource server SHOULD NOT include an error code or other error information.

comment.title: Access token in URI is insecure
comment.explain: The query string of this request’s URI contains an ‘access_token’ parameter. It’s probably a bearer token, as defined in .
comment.rfc: Bearer tokens SHOULD NOT be passed in page URLs (for example, as query string parameters). Instead, bearer tokens SHOULD be passed in HTTP message headers or message bodies for which confidentiality measures are taken. Browsers, web servers, and other software may not adequately secure URLs in the browser history, web server logs, and other data structures. If bearer tokens are passed in page URLs, attackers might be able to steal them from the history data, logs, or other unsecured locations.

comment.title: Access token may need TLS
comment.explain: This request has an ‘access_token’ parameter. It’s probably a bearer token, as defined in .
comment.rfc: Clients MUST always use TLS [RFC5246] (https) or equivalent transport security when making requests with bearer tokens. Failing to do so exposes the token to numerous attacks that could give attackers unintended access.

comment.title: Access token in URI needs “Cache-Control: no-store”
comment.explain: According to , if an access token is sent in the request URI, then the request should at least have a “Cache-Control: no-store” header. This reduces the risk of caches saving this token.

error.title: Malformed : Basic
error.explain: A Basic authentication challenge must have parameters as “key=value” pairs. See .

error.title: header without credentials
error.explain: An header usually consists of two parts: the name of the authentication scheme, and the actual credentials. But in this request, it only contains the scheme (“”).
Was something like “: Bearer ” intended?
See also .

comment.title: Entity declarations in XML may cause problems
comment.explain: This message’s XML content includes entity declarations (<!ENTITY>). Many XML applications do not process such declarations because they can lead to denial-of-service attacks.

error.title: : is as good as
error.explain: The header is not an ordered list. Whether comes before or after , does not affect its priority. Only explicit quality values (q=) count.
In other words, this request says that any is as acceptable as .
To make a fallback, it should have a lower quality value, for example: ;q=0.1
See .

comment.title: Obsolete ‘X-’ prefix in headers
comment.explain: Adding an ‘X-’ prefix to “experimental” headers is an old practice that is now considered obsolete. See .
For custom headers that may be generally useful, it’s best to drop the ‘X-’ prefix (but check the to avoid collisions with existing names).
For private headers not intended to be used by others, ‘X-’ can be replaced with something like the organization’s name.

comment.title: Missing reverse stream
comment.explain: There is a stream file , but there is no corresponding stream file for the reverse direction. HTTPolice will try to process this file on its own.

error.title: Unprocessable streams
error.explain: HTTPolice has found the following stream files:
file 1:
file 2:
but cannot detect which of them is the inbound stream and which is the outbound.
This means that the connection was not HTTP/1.x, or was encrypted, or that the files are somehow malformed. They will not be processed.

comment.title: ‘charset’ parameter is undefined for application/json
comment.explain: The application/json media type does not have a ‘charset’ parameter. Adding one really has no effect on compliant recipients.
See also .

error.title: JSON can’t be encoded in
error.rfc: JSON text SHALL be encoded in UTF-8, UTF-16, or UTF-32.

error.title: Wrong media type ‘’ in
error.explain: There is no such media type ‘’. Probably ‘’ was intended.

comment.title: Cacheable 421 response may cause problems
comment.explain: 421 responses are defined as cacheable by default. However, because of how an HTTP cache works (), it is harmful to cache a 421 response, as it would be returned on subsequent requests to the same URI, without even trying to connect to the right server.
To avoid this, a 421 response to should be marked as non-cacheable with a header like “Cache-Control: no-store”.
See .

comment.title: 202 response should have a body
comment.rfc: The representation sent with this response ought to describe the request's current status and point to (or embed) a status monitor that can provide the user with an estimate of when the request will be fulfilled.

comment.title: Duplicate ‘’ token in Prefer
comment.rfc: To avoid any possible ambiguity, individual preference tokens SHOULD NOT appear multiple times within a single request.

error.title: Preference-Applied: was not requested
error.explain: “Preference-Applied: ” means that the server honored the client’s preference . But the client did not request in its Prefer header.

error.title: request cannot Prefer: respond-async
error.explain: The whole point of a request is to retrieve information from the server. It’s impossible to respond asynchronously to such a request: the response would not contain the requested information.

error.title: GET request cannot Prefer: return=minimal
error.explain: The whole point of a GET request is to retrieve a representation of the resource (as in “return=representation”). There is no “minimal” response that could satisfy this request.
Instead, the Accept header could be used to select the desired kind of representation.

error.title: Prefer: return=minimal contradicts return=representation
error.rfc: The "return=minimal" and "return=representation" preferences are mutually exclusive directives.

error.title: Prefer: handling=strict contradicts handling=lenient
error.rfc: The "handling=strict" and "handling=lenient" preferences are mutually exclusive directives.

comment.title: Response with Preference-Applied may need “Vary: Prefer”
comment.rfc: If a server supports the optional application of a preference that might result in a variance to a cache's handling of a response entity, a Vary header field MUST be included in the response listing the Prefer header field

error.title: Method ‘’ should probably be ‘’
error.rfc: The method token is case-sensitive

error.title: Duplicate ‘’ parameter in
error.rfc: Each parameter MUST NOT occur more than once per field-value.

comment.title: Possibly bad syntax in
comment.explain: The Forwarded header here contains elements, describing proxy hops, with only one parameter for each proxy — yet all parameters have different names.
If this was intended to be parameters for a single proxy hop, then the pairs must be separated with semicolons, not commas.

debug.title: Body is too long to be checked
debug.explain: This message’s indicates that the body is at least bytes long. HTTPolice does not attempt to process bodies longer than bytes. The rest of the stream will not be processed either.
